div1.head: Letter from Walter D. McCaw to Mark Sullivan, July 14, 1925
div1.opener:
McCaw to
Mark Sullivan
7/16/'25
Y. F.
wdm ell
McCaw's Comments on
Mr Mark Sullivan's
Chapter on Gorgas and
Y. F.
July 14, 1925.
Mr. Mark Sullivan,
91 Home Life Building,
Washington, D. C.
My dear Mr. Sullivan:
div1.p:
Referring to your letter of July 10th inclosing a copy of an article
on General Gorgas, I must first state that I never had the honor of personal
service with General Gorgas, either in Havana or on the Canal Zone. Perhaps
you have confounded my name and that of General R. E. Noble, now retired.
However, it was my duty to look into the history of the fight against yellow
fever, when on duty in the Surgeon General's Office, and I venture therefore,
having read your very interesting article, to make a few suggestions which I
hope may be of use to you. These, however, will apply only to the Havana
period, as I am not competent to speak from personal knowledge on any of the
matters connected with General Gorgas's sanitary administration of the Panama
Canal Zone. The following notes are simply intended to clear up what appears
to me to be a few doubtful points in your narrative:

Page 4: General Gorgas was present at an epidemic at Fort Brown and
the city of Brownsville, Texas, in 1882, being himself infected. I do
not think that he personally saw yellow fever cases from that time until
1897 at Barrancas, where there was a moderate epidemic; nor again after
that until he went to Cuba.

Page 5: It was not Gorgas's job to clean up Havana, so far as the
streets were concerned. This was done by Major William M. Black, U. S.
Corps of Engineers, afterwards Chief of Engineers, and it was under
General Ludlow, commanding in the city of Havana. The premises, such
as backyards and patios, were cleaned up by the Sanitary Department,
but the sanitary officer, Major Davis, was also under General Ludlow,
reporting directly to him. Gorgas did not have charge, therefore, of
Mr. Mark Sullivan - 2.
any of the actual policing of Havana until about February, 1900. It is
hardly fair, therefore, to credit him with cleaning up Havana of the
accumulated filth of years.
(See General Kean's review of Mrs. Gorgas's book.)

Page 6: The American Army of invasion, Shafter's army at Santiago,
was indeed saturated with fever, but it was largely malarial in nature.
There were some cases of yellow fever in the rear of the army - how many
will never be known - but the large majority of fever-stricken soldiers
that were returned to Montauk Point were purely malarial cases. I rather
think you give the impression that the American and Spanish armies were
fever-stricken with yellow fever

Page 9: Note. Dr. Henry R. Carter, U. S. Public Health Service, knew
nothing about incubation in the mosquito, which your statement would
indicate. His careful study of the period of incubation of yellow fever
in patients, briefly stated, shows that a non-immune going into an
infected locality develops the disease in the usual period, less than
ten days; whereas when an infected person goes to an uninfected locality
twenty days or more must elapse before new cases develop. This indicates
an incubation of the disease cause somewhere outside of the human body.
Carter called this “extrinsic incubation”. It was not explained until
the Reed experiments were made. Carter's observations were undoubtedly
very suggestive and valuable to Reed.
Mr. Mark Sullivan - 3.

Page 10: Carroll's inoculation was a methodical experiment by Lazear
and it succeeded, as one of the mosquitoes used had been infected 12
days before. Lazear's infection was accidental from a free mosquito
in the yellow fever ward. He noticed the bite, however, and it no
doubt caused his attack, from which he died.

Page 12: Permanent receptacles of water, such as barrels and cisterns,
were listed and regularly inspected. A/s to every small receptacle capable
of holding water being catalogued and accounted for at each inspection,
I rather think this to be impossible and that any account given to this
effect is more or less fanciful.

Page 17: I am inclined to believe that Oswaldo Cruz, using the Gorgas
method, cleaned up yellow fever in Rio de Janeiro in 1909 and not Buenos
Aires, prior to Gorgas's work in Panama.

Page 20: Dr. C. A. L. Reed's visit to Panama was not fortuitous. He was
sent there by Mr. Taft, when Secretary of War. (See Kean's review).

Page 28: Preparations for war were made by the Surgeon General's Office
in accordance with plans that had been long in existence. The Medical
Reserve Corps of the Army was increased quite largely during the mobiliza-
tion of troops on the Texas border in 1915-1916, during which years General
Gorgas was absent for quite a long time in Peru engaged in yellow fever
work, Colonel Birmingham being the Acting Surgeon General.
Mr. Mark Sullivan - 4.

Page 29: (top) I may say that, whereas General Gorgas was of course the
responsible head of the Medical Department of the United States Army and,
in common with the rest of the War Department, did everything possible to
furnish in a most liberal manner men, money, and supplies to the Army in
France, the provision of hospitals, the management and establishment of
the same were entirely in the hands of the Medical Department of the
A.E.F., and the bureau chiefs in Washington assumed no authority in the
matter. In fact it may be said that the A.E.F., under General Pershing
and the G.H.Q. at Chaumont, was entirely autonomous and did its own
fighting and administration.

I hope the above notes will be of some use to you. And now I may be
pardoned for one other criticism, which interests me solely because the credit
for the great conquest of yellow fever seems to a certain extent to be diverted--
certainly in the public mind -- from the one who most truly deserves it.

You give a very clear though brief account of Walter Reed's experiments
and then relate the brilliant result of Gorgas's putting this new knowledge into
effect. It reminds me of a story, which you probably read as I did in your
youth, to be found in the ordinary version of the “Arabian Nights”. In this
story Habib, an Arabian prince, was called upon to rescue a captive princess
from the hands of a legion of very powerful and malignant genii who were holding
her in captivity. With a considerable amount of supernatural aid Habib was
carried by a friendly roc to the bowels of Mt. Caucasus, where the treasure
of King Solomon was hidden, guarded by benevolent genii. He was permitted to
take therefrom the magic sword of Solomon engraved with the word “POWER”.
Armed with this he was enabled to put to flight all of the evil spirits that
attacked him in the form of horrible monsters of different kinds. By waving
his sword and uttering the word of POWER, these monsters disappeared, disin-
tegrated or fled before him, and he finally rescued the princess.

It seems to me that Reed, in this great fight against yellow fever,
forged the sword of Solomon and engraved thereon the word of POWER. All honor
to General Gorgas and everyone else who afterwards wielded this irresistible
weapon in the fight against yellow Jack, but the conqueror of Yellow Jack is
the forger of the sword and not the wielder thereof.

General J. R. Kean, retired, now Editor of “The Military Surgeon”,
has this morning gone over your article with me, and these remarks and sug-
gestions are made with his help. General Kean went to Cuba as Chief Surgeon
Mr. Mark Sullivan - 5.
of the Seventh Army Corps, under Fitzhugh Lee, and was afterwards Chief of
the Department of Beneficencia, under the American Governor of Cuba. He is
intimately acquainted with all of the work against yellow fever that went on
in Havana. I inclose you a copy of his editorial reviewing the recent
biography of General Gorgas by his wife, and I also take the liberty of
inclosing one of the few remaining copies of a little memoir of Walter Reed
which I wrote in 1903 in the interests of the Walter Reed Memorial Association.
You may find in them something to assist you.

I would suggest that, in case you would like to have the aid and
testimony of one closely associated with General Gorgas during the Panama
Canal period of his career, you communicate with General R. E. Noble, retired,
who lives in Anniston, Alabama, but who is now in Washington for, I think, a
few weeks, and whose address is c/o Mrs. M. R. Tyssowski, 2019 Columbia Road,
N.W.

Your paper has interested me very much and I thank you for the
opportunity of seeing it and commenting upon it.
div1.closer:
Faithfully yours, Walter D. McCaw,
Brigadier General, Med. Dept.,
Assistant Surgeon General. 2 Incls.
